column4: I'm trying to mount a SD card, mount: /dev/sdc: can't read superblock
most likely you need to use /dev/sdc1
try fdisk -l /dev/sdc.  If it shows a partition table, then use sdc1
what does   sudo fdisk -l /dev/sdc     do?
that's not possible.  It can give you an error, or it can display something, but it can't do nothing.
try with -v
yes, sorry, that's not right.  Let me check the flags ...
try    sfdisk -l /dev/sdc
see if it says "can't open for reading"
try this (to see if the thing can be accessed at all):   sudo dd if=/dev/sdc of=/dev/null bs=512 count=1
so what should i do?
did you try the dd command?  There's so much traffic I'm not sure whether you responded to that suggestion.
when you connect the thing, do you see messages at the end of  dmesg showing the USB port and then which sdX is used?
it does a continuous error loop
ok, well, nothing good will happen until that gets fixed.
the write cache message is normal, but READ CAPACITY failed is not normal.
the first thing I'd try is checking the kernel configuration, make sure the modules are loaded for your box's USB hardware.
if you are using a card reader, try a different card reader.
I've used SD cards on here before ,just bought this card, I've lways had problems like these with the cards (it's a laptop, internal reader)
I would try an external reader, that will at least tell us if it's the reader or the card.
it's without a doubt the card.
obviously if it's the card there isn't anything you can do except get another card (which I realize isn't terribly helpful but is true).
